childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1949-1961

The smell of Silly Putty, fresh from the egg. The satisfying bounce of a Slinky walking down the stairs. The weight of a cap gun in your hand, the sulfur smoke after pulling the trigger. Your childhood had a texture that kids today will never know—everything was tactile, imaginative, real.

At five, you were glued to Howdy Doody, watching Buffalo Bob Smith ask 'Hey kids, what time is it?' You knew the answer by heart. The Lone Ranger crackled from the radio before it moved to television. Captain Video and His Video Rangers. Kukla, Fran and Ollie. You begged your parents to let you stay up for I Love Lucy, which premiered when you were two and became the show everyone talked about at school.

Your toys were simpler but somehow more alive. Lincoln Logs and Erector Sets that actually required building something. Tinker Toys. Roy Rogers cap guns and cowboy outfits because everyone wanted to be a cowboy. Betsy Wetsy dolls that actually wet their diapers—a technological marvel. You played marbles on the sidewalk, kept score, and traded them like currency.

Dinner came from cans that felt modern. Campbell's soup—you knew the red and white label before you could read. Swanson TV dinners arrived when you were five, aluminum trays with compartments that kept the turkey away from the peas. Spam was still considered acceptable protein. Jell-O molds at every church potluck, often with fruit suspended inside like prehistoric insects in amber.

At six, you practiced duck-and-cover drills, crawling under your wooden desk as if it could stop an atomic bomb. The Rosenbergs were executed when you were four. McCarthy's hearings played on the television your family gathered around like a shrine. The communists were everywhere, your teachers said—in Hollywood, in the State Department, maybe even in your neighborhood. You didn't fully understand the threat, but you understood fear.

At eight, you watched the Little Rock Nine on television—nine Black students walking through a mob of screaming white adults just to go to school. You were old enough to understand injustice, even if the adults around you pretended it was more complicated than it was.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Baby Boomers

Baby Boomer. The term started as demography and became an accusation. You're part of the 76 million Americans born between 1946 and 1964—the generation so large it reshaped every institution it touched. Schools, jobs, housing, culture: all bent around your sheer numbers. You're an early Boomer, born in the first wave, which means you were old enough to actually remember the sixties. Not the nostalgia version. The real thing.

You were fourteen when JFK was assassinated. November 22, 1963. You remember exactly where you were—everyone your age does. Eighth grade, probably. A teacher crying. The principal's announcement. The walk home feeling like the world had cracked open. Everything before that day was innocence. Everything after was something else.

Your generation spans 1946 to 1964—the largest demographic wave in American history until the Millennials caught up. You overwhelmed schools in the fifties, flooded colleges in the sixties, dominated workplaces in the seventies. Wherever you went, infrastructure struggled to accommodate you. Being numerous was a form of power you rarely acknowledged.

You were twenty during the Summer of Love. Old enough to participate, young enough to believe it meant something. Free love, peace signs, flower power—and also the draft lottery, body counts on the evening news, friends who came back different or didn't come back at all. The sixties weren't just tie-dye and Woodstock. They were also Birmingham and Tet and My Lai.

Your generation gets blamed for everything now: the housing crisis, the climate crisis, the wealth gap, the political polarization. Some of it is fair. You did pull up ladders. You did ignore warnings. But you also marched for civil rights, protested an unjust war, and pushed for equality in ways your parents never imagined. The contradiction is that you did both—changed the world and then protected your piece of it.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

Gene Autry's 'Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer' came out the year you were born. You've heard it approximately forty thousand times since. Arthur Miller's Death of a Salesman won the Pulitzer that year—prescient, given how much of your life would be shaped by the American Dream and its discontents. Rodgers and Hammerstein's South Pacific taught America to be 'carefully taught,' even if the lesson didn't stick.

Your childhood soundtrack was the transition from radio to television. At four, you listened to The Lone Ranger on the radio with your father. At seven, you watched it on the new TV set in the living room—the one the whole neighborhood came to see. Howdy Doody. The Mickey Mouse Club. Ding Dong School for the little kids, Davy Crockett for everyone. You wanted a coonskin cap. Everyone wanted a coonskin cap.

At seven, rock and roll arrived like a bomb. Bill Haley's 'Rock Around the Clock' in 1954. Then Elvis on Ed Sullivan when you were seven—your parents horrified, you transformed. Little Richard screaming 'Tutti Frutti.' Chuck Berry duck-walking across the stage. Buddy Holly with those glasses. The sound split generations in half, and you were on the right side of the divide.

By high school, it was the early sixties. You were fifteen when the Beatles appeared on Ed Sullivan—February 9, 1964. Seventy-three million people watching. You were sixteen during the British Invasion: the Rolling Stones, the Who, the Kinks. You were eighteen during the Summer of Love, twenty when the White Album dropped, twenty when they played on the rooftop. Your teenage years had the greatest soundtrack in American history, and you knew it even then.

Movies grew up with you. You saw Bambi and Cinderella as a kid, Ten Commandments and Ben-Hur as a teenager. Then Bonnie and Clyde when you were eighteen—violence and sex that would have been unthinkable five years earlier. The Graduate at eighteen, Easy Rider at twenty. American cinema went from wholesome to subversive in the time it took you to get a driver's license.

By your thirties, you were watching All in the Family and M*A*S*H—shows that took the idealism you'd felt at twenty and gave it a bitter, knowing edge. By your forties, Hill Street Blues and Miami Vice. You've watched television evolve from three channels of innocence to five hundred channels of prestige nihilism. You were there for all of it.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

The rotary dial on your parents' telephone—that satisfying resistance, the whir as it spun back. The party line you shared with neighbors, where you could pick up and hear Mrs. Henderson gossiping if you were quiet enough. The operator who connected long-distance calls, which cost so much your parents timed them with a kitchen timer. This was communication when you were five.

At six, your family probably got their first television set—a hulking wooden cabinet with a tiny screen and rabbit ears that needed constant adjustment. You watched test patterns while waiting for actual programming to start. You adjusted the vertical hold. You learned that banging the side of the cabinet sometimes fixed the picture. Three channels, maybe, if the weather was right. Black and white until you were fifteen, when color arrived like a revelation.

At eight, Sputnik blinked across the night sky, and America panicked. The Space Race became the national obsession of your adolescence. You were twenty when Neil Armstrong stepped onto the moon—July 20, 1969. You watched it live, grainy footage beamed from a quarter-million miles away, and it felt like the future had finally arrived. Humanity went from Kitty Hawk to the lunar surface in sixty-six years. You were alive for most of that progression.

At twenty-eight, the Apple II appeared. At thirty-two, the IBM PC. Computers were curiosities, then tools, then inescapable. You might have been an early adopter, bringing a PC into your office when colleagues thought you were eccentric. Or you might have resisted until resistance became impossible. Either way, you learned to type on a keyboard after decades of secretaries handling that task.

At forty-six, the World Wide Web arrived. At fifty-five, Google. At fifty-eight, Facebook. At fifty-eight, the iPhone. Each wave of technology required adaptation that younger people never had to consciously make. You remember when 'online' was a place you went, not a state of being. You remember when 'phone' meant a device attached to a wall.

The gulf between your childhood technology and now is almost incomprehensible. You were born into rotary phones and propeller planes. You're living with smartphones and SpaceX. No generation before you experienced this much change, and no generation after will find it as disorienting. You're the last people alive who remember what the world was like before.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

Where were you when you heard about Sputnik? October 4, 1957. You were eight years old, and suddenly the Soviets were in space, beeping overhead, while America scrambled to catch up. The adults were frightened in a way you hadn't seen before—not even during the duck-and-cover drills. This fear was different. This fear was about falling behind.

At thirteen, the Cuban Missile Crisis. October 1962. Thirteen days when nuclear war felt not just possible but probable. You were old enough to understand what the grown-ups were whispering about. Old enough to feel the fear. Your family might have stocked the basement with canned goods. Some of your classmates' families built fallout shelters. The world almost ended, and you knew it.

At fourteen, JFK was shot—your generation's defining moment, detailed in the generational identity section. The shock waves from that November day shaped everything that followed: escalating Vietnam, the counterculture, the collapse of institutional trust.

At nineteen, MLK was assassinated. April 4, 1968. Two months later, RFK. The sixties were supposed to be about hope, but by 1968, hope was being gunned down in Memphis and Los Angeles. Cities burned. The Democratic Convention in Chicago became a police riot. You were twenty, draft-eligible, watching the country tear itself apart.

Vietnam defined your young adulthood. You were sixteen when the Gulf of Tonkin resolution passed. Nineteen when the draft lottery started. Twenty-six when Saigon fell. If you're male, you either served, got a deferment, fled to Canada, or spent years with that lottery number hanging over your life. You knew people who didn't come back. You knew people who came back different. The war shaped you even if you never went.

At twenty, you watched men walk on the moon. At twenty-four, you watched a president resign. At forty, you watched the Berlin Wall fall—the enemy you'd been trained to fear since childhood suddenly vanishing. At fifty-two, you watched towers collapse in New York. At seventy-one, a pandemic made you the vulnerable demographic. You've lived through the entire arc of the American Century, from triumphant beginning to uncertain present.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

Let's talk about what the economy looked like when you entered it. Not the nostalgia version—the actual numbers.

You graduated college around 1971, if you went. The unemployment rate was 6%. Not great, but manageable. More importantly, a college degree actually meant something—roughly 11% of Americans had one, so you were rare, valuable. A high school diploma alone could get you a union job at a factory that paid enough to buy a house and support a family. The implicit bargain was clear: work hard, stay loyal, and the company would take care of you. For many of you, they did.

You probably had two or three employers across your entire career. Maybe just one. You stayed because loyalty was rewarded with pensions, promotions, job security. The company Christmas party had an open bar. The gold watch at retirement wasn't a joke—it was a ritual. Try explaining this to a Millennial who's had four jobs in six years because that's the only way to get a raise.

If you're a woman, your career was constrained by barriers that are hard to explain to anyone who didn't live them. Help wanted ads were legally segregated by gender until 1973—you were twenty-four before that changed. Sexual harassment wasn't legally recognized until 1986. The glass ceiling wasn't a metaphor; it was architecture. Every promotion required fighting battles that younger women often don't realize were fought.

The workplace transformed around you more than any generation before. You started with typewriters, carbon copies, secretarial pools. You ended with email, spreadsheets, everyone doing their own typing. You learned to use computers in your forties, smartphones in your sixties. Adapting wasn't optional—it was survival.

The pension promises started breaking in the eighties. Corporate raiders. Hostile takeovers. Shareholder value. The implicit contract between employer and employee—loyalty for security—was shredded by people who'd never built anything, only extracted. You watched it happen, helpless to stop it, often benefiting from the short-term gains while the long-term costs were deferred to younger workers.

You're retired now, or approaching it. Social Security exists because your generation votes. Medicare exists because crossing seniors is political suicide. These programs are less certain for those who follow, which they resent—not entirely without reason.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Did you ever call a girl's house and hang up when her father answered? Did you ever drive past someone's house just to see if their car was there? Did you ever wait by the phone—the one phone, attached to the wall—hoping they'd call? Romance before technology was physical, nerve-wracking, and required courage that swiping right will never demand.

The Pill was approved when you were eleven. By the time you were dating seriously, contraception had rewritten the rules—but not evenly. The sexual revolution was more revolutionary for some than others. Women your age navigated a narrow path between 'prude' and 'loose,' judged for both extremes. Men had more freedom, as men generally did. The double standard didn't disappear; it just got more complicated.

You probably married younger than any generation since. The median age for first marriage in 1970 was twenty-one for women, twenty-three for men. You got married before you knew who you were, which is why roughly half of your generation's first marriages ended in divorce. You normalized blended families because you had to. Step-parents, half-siblings, complicated holiday logistics—your generation invented the modern family, for better and worse.

Courtship meant drive-in movies and milkshakes. Going steady meant his class ring on a chain around your neck. Long-distance relationships required actual letters, written by hand, sent through the mail, received days later. You waited for the mailman the way your grandchildren wait for text notifications. The anticipation was exquisite, and nothing digital has quite replicated it.

Your friendships were bound by geography. Your friends were people you saw regularly—neighbors, coworkers, church members, bowling league teammates. When someone moved away, the friendship often faded because maintaining it required effort that felt insurmountable: expensive long-distance calls, letters that needed writing, visits that needed planning. You lost touch with people in ways that seem impossible now.

You have grandchildren, probably. Great-grandchildren, possibly. You've learned to FaceTime, to text, to navigate group chats where three generations communicate in the same thread. You've adapted to technology you never imagined, staying connected across distances that would have meant goodbye in your youth. The adaptation often goes unacknowledged, but it's remarkable.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Your parents remembered the bread lines. They remembered when banks failed and savings vanished overnight. They remembered when prosperity wasn't a birthright but a fragile gift that could be snatched away. You inherited their caution—the coffee cans of cash hidden in the basement, the suspicion of debt, the belief that you should always be ready for the floor to drop out.

But you also grew up during the greatest economic expansion in American history. The postwar boom wasn't propaganda; it was your lived experience. A single income could support a family of four, a house, a car, a vacation. Your father's factory job came with a pension, health insurance, and the expectation that loyalty would be rewarded with security. The cognitive dissonance between your parents' Depression-era fear and your own abundant reality created a complicated psychology.

The numbers tell the story of your advantage. The median home price in 1970 was $23,000—about three times the median household income. You could buy a house on a middle-class salary, pay it off in fifteen years, watch it appreciate 400% while you slept. Today that same ratio would mean houses cost $200,000. They don't. They cost $400,000, $500,000, more. The math that worked for you doesn't work anymore.

You rode the great bull markets: the 1980s, the 1990s, the post-2008 recovery. You survived the crashes too—1987, 2000, 2008—but if you stayed invested, you recovered. Time was on your side in ways it isn't for people starting later. Compound interest requires decades. You had them.

Your generation holds more wealth than any in American history—the comparison section details the staggering gap. This isn't because younger generations work less hard. It's because assets appreciated before they could buy them, wages stagnated while costs climbed, and the policies that helped you—affordable education, strong unions, defined-benefit pensions—were dismantled.

The intergenerational tension is real, and it's not entirely unfair. You didn't steal your wealth. You worked for it, saved it, benefited from timing you didn't control. But the playing field wasn't level. Acknowledging that costs you nothing and might matter more than you think.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your lived experience has become a lens that distorts the present. The economy that rewarded your hard work doesn't exist anymore. The housing market you navigated was fundamentally different. The job market you entered bears no resemblance to what younger people face. Your experience was real, but it's not replicable. The advice you offer, however well-intentioned, describes a world that ended decades ago.

You tend to underestimate how much systemic advantages shaped your success. The GI Bill sent your generation to college on the government's dime—but not Black veterans, who were systematically excluded. Affordable housing existed because redlining and racial covenants concentrated investment in white neighborhoods. Strong unions protected your wages while excluding minorities from membership. The prosperity you remember wasn't universal; it was rationed. Acknowledging this doesn't diminish your work. It contextualizes it.

Mental health carries a stigma you might not realize you're perpetuating. Depression was weakness. Anxiety was worry. Trauma was something you got over, not something you processed. The stoicism that helped your parents survive the Depression and World War II calcified, in your generation, into a resistance to emotional vulnerability. When your grandchildren talk about therapy, about boundaries, about mental health days, the eye-roll might be imperceptible—but they notice it.

Technology bewilders you more than you'd like to admit. You've adapted, yes—you have a smartphone, you use email—but the intuition isn't there. You still print emails. You still fall for phishing scams at higher rates than any other demographic. You still think of the digital world as separate from the real world, which it hasn't been for decades. The internet isn't a place you visit; it's the infrastructure of modern life.

Climate change is the blind spot that will define your generation's legacy. You were adults when the science became clear—the first comprehensive climate report was published in 1979, when you were thirty. You had political and economic power to address it. Meaningful action didn't happen. Your grandchildren will inherit a different planet, and they will have questions. The answers—'we didn't know,' 'it was complicated,' 'someone else's job'—won't satisfy them. They shouldn't.

The deepest blind spot may be this: you think you earned everything you have, and you did—but on a playing field that was tilted in your favor by policies, timing, and demographics. Younger generations aren't failing to replicate your success because they're lazy or entitled. They're failing because the game changed, and nobody told them the new rules.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1969-1979): This was supposed to be the decade of revolution, and in some ways it was. You were twenty during the Summer of Love, twenty during the moon landing, twenty during Woodstock. You protested the war, embraced the counterculture, believed you could change the world. You also got drafted, got married young, got jobs that actually paid enough to live on. The economy was strong until the oil crisis hit in 1973. Then stagflation—the economic anomaly that wasn't supposed to exist. Your idealistic decade ended with disco, malaise, gas lines, and the Iranian hostage crisis playing on television every night.

Your 30s (1979-1989): Reagan's America. The counterculture gave way to conservatism—or you held onto your principles while the culture moved right. You settled into careers, raised children, moved to suburbs that looked like the ones you'd grown up in. AIDS emerged and terrified everyone. The Cold War froze deeper. Wall Street boomed. Gordon Gekko proclaimed that greed was good. Yuppies were invented, and you might have been one, or you might have mocked them while secretly envying their BMWs. This was the decade of Morning in America, whether you bought the slogan or not.

Your 40s (1989-1999): Everything you'd been told to fear your entire life simply vanished. The Berlin Wall fell. The Soviet Union collapsed. The Cold War ended not with a bang but with champagne and sledgehammers. The existential threat of your childhood was suddenly history. The nineties brought the Clinton boom, the internet, globalization's promises. Your kids became teenagers—incomprehensible and expensive. Your parents started aging—needing more, giving less. You were firmly middle-aged, sandwiched between generations, responsible for everyone.

Your 50s (1999-2009): You entered this decade at the peak of American triumphalism. The Cold War won. The economy booming. Y2K a fizzle. The future looked like more of the present, only better. Then September 11, 2001. You were fifty-two. Old enough to have perspective on tragedy, young enough to be shaken to your core. Wars in Afghanistan and Iraq followed. The housing bubble inflated, and you watched your home equity climb. Then 2008: the crash, the bailouts, your 401(k) cut in half. Your fifties began in optimism and ended in rubble.

Your 60s (2009-2019): Recovery—though perhaps not complete recovery. The economy improved, slowly. You retired, or started planning for it seriously. Grandchildren arrived. Your health became something you thought about more than you used to—the checkups, the medications, the mortality that had been theoretical becoming concrete. Politics grew more polarized. The world your grandchildren inhabited seemed foreign: all screens and anxiety and climate news. You voted, because your generation always votes, and politicians knew it.

Your 70s (2019-2029): You're here now. COVID-19 arrived when you were seventy and put you in the vulnerable category—a demographic designation that felt like a verdict. The world changed again, as it keeps doing. You're navigating late life in a country that sometimes feels unrecognizable from the one you grew up in. Your generation still holds wealth, political power, institutional authority. The question isn't what you accomplished—it's what you do with the years that remain, and how you're remembered when they're gone.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

3.6 million people were born in the US the same year as you. You're part of the 76 million Americans classified as Baby Boomers—the largest generation in American history until Millennials edged you out. Your demographic weight bent every institution you touched: schools, jobs, housing, politics. Being numerous was power, even if you rarely named it as such.

Compared to the Silent Generation (born 1928-1945): They remembered the bread lines. They fought the war or lived through its deprivations. Scarcity shaped them—made them cautious, conformist, grateful for stability. You grew up during abundance, which made you confident enough to question everything they'd accepted. You were the generation that said 'don't trust anyone over 30,' then turned 30 and expected to be trusted. They saved their money and kept their heads down. You bought houses and demanded attention.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): They grew up in your shadow, literally. Smaller cohort, fewer resources, less attention. By the time they entered the workforce, you'd taken the entry-level jobs and weren't leaving. By the time they wanted promotions, you were blocking the ladder. They're sometimes called the forgotten generation—sandwiched between Boomers who won't retire and Millennials who complain more loudly. The resentment is quiet but real.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): You had every economic advantage, and the numbers prove it. You bought houses when median home prices were three times median income. They're buying (or not buying) when it's six times. You got pensions. They got 401(k)s and the advice to 'just invest.' You graduated without debt. They graduated with $30,000 average, into the worst job market since the Great Depression—the one your generation's financial system created. The intergenerational resentment is real, and it's not entirely unfair.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): You're from different planets. They don't remember a world before smartphones. They've never known economic security as anything other than an abstraction. Climate change isn't a future threat to them—it's the present, the water they swim in. You have grandchildren their age. The gap between your childhood and theirs is so vast it's almost anthropological. They watch you with a mixture of curiosity and judgment, trying to understand how you could have had so much and done so little with the knowledge you had.

Your life expectancy at birth was 68 years. If you've made it to 75, you can expect to live into your mid-80s. Medical advances have extended your life—though they've also extended the period of decline, the years of managing conditions rather than curing them. You'll spend more time in retirement than your parents did, which is a mixed blessing: more years, but more expensive years.

Your generation's legacy is genuinely complicated. You changed the world—marched for civil rights, pushed for feminism, launched the environmental movement, built the technology age. You also accumulated wealth while pulling up ladders, ignored climate warnings when action was still easy, and presided over the greatest inequality since the Gilded Age. History will judge you, as it judges every generation. The verdict isn't in yet, but the evidence is mounting.

year_events: Mao proclaimed the People's Republic of China
The Soviet Union tested its first atomic bomb
Germany was divided into East and West
